next_sentence: Only one dog remained alive; but there was a human being within it whom the sailors were persuading to enter the vessel.

question: She was no longer that happy creature who in earlier youth wandered with me on the banks of the lake and [MASK] with ecstasy of our future prospects.
source_info: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus by Shelley, Mary W.
title: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus
prev_sentence: Elizabeth was sad and desponding; she no longer took delight in her ordinary occupations; all pleasure seemed to her sacrilege toward the dead; eternal woe and tears she then thought was the just tribute she should pay to innocence so blasted and destroyed.
next_sentence: The first of those sorrows which are sent to wean us from the earth had visited her, and its dimming influence quenched her dearest smiles.

question: During this voyage we passed many willowy islands and saw several beautiful [MASK].
source_info: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus by Shelley, Mary W.
title: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus
prev_sentence: We had agreed to descend the Rhine in a boat from Strasburgh to Rotterdam, whence we might take shipping for London.
next_sentence: We stayed a day at Mannheim, and on the fifth from our departure from Strasburgh, arrived at Mainz.

question: Turning towards the [MASK], he said, âWhat do you mean?
source_info: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus by Shelley, Mary W.
title: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus

question: He excites at once my admiration and my pity to an astonishing [MASK].
source_info: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus by Shelley, Mary W.
title: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus
prev_sentence: My affection for my guest increases every day.
next_sentence: How can I see so noble a creature destroyed by misery without feeling the most poignant grief?

question: Men who before this change seemed to have been hid in [MASK] dispersed themselves and were employed in various arts of cultivation.
source_info: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus by Shelley, Mary W.
title: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus
prev_sentence: âThe pleasant showers and genial warmth of spring greatly altered the aspect of the earth.
next_sentence: The birds sang in more cheerful notes, and the leaves began to bud forth on the trees.

question: The winter, however, was spent cheerfully; and although the spring was uncommonly late, when it came its [MASK] compensated for its dilatoriness.
source_info: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus by Shelley, Mary W.
title: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus
prev_sentence: My return had only been delayed so long, from an unwillingness to leave Clerval in a strange place, before he had become acquainted with any of its inhabitants.
next_sentence: The month of May had already commenced, and I expected the letter daily which was to fix the date of my departure, when Henry proposed a pedestrian tour in the environs of Ingolstadt, that I might bid a personal farewell to the country I had so long inhabited.

question: Beaufort had taken effectual [MASK] to conceal himself, and it was ten months before my father discovered his abode.
source_info: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus by Shelley, Mary W.
title: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus
prev_sentence: He lost no time in endeavouring to seek him out, with the hope of persuading him to begin the world again through his credit and assistance.
next_sentence: Overjoyed at this discovery, he hastened to the house, which was situated in a mean street near the Reuss.

question: She indeed [MASK] her grief and strove to act the comforter to us all.
source_info: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus by Shelley, Mary W.
title: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus
prev_sentence: I was unwilling to quit the sight of those that remained to me, and above all, I desired to see my sweet Elizabeth in some degree consoled.
next_sentence: She looked steadily on life and assumed its duties with courage and zeal.

question: No one can conceive the variety of [MASK] which bore me onwards, like a hurricane, in the first enthusiasm of success.
source_info: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus by Shelley, Mary W.
title: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus
prev_sentence: After having formed this determination and having spent some months in successfully collecting and arranging my materials, I began.

next_sentence: âWhen she had finished, she gave the guitar to Agatha, who at first declined it.

question: Everything is related in them which bears reference to my accursed origin; the whole detail of that series of disgusting circumstances which produced it is set in view; the minutest description of my odious and loathsome person is [MASK], in language which painted your own horrors and rendered mine indelible.
source_info: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus by Shelley, Mary W.
title: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus
prev_sentence: Here they are.

question: The cold is excessive, and many of my unfortunate [MASK] have already found a grave amidst this scene of desolation.
source_info: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus by Shelley, Mary W.
title: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus
prev_sentence: We are still surrounded by mountains of ice, still in imminent danger of being crushed in their conflict.
next_sentence: Frankenstein has daily declined in health; a feverish fire still glimmers in his eyes, but he is exhausted, and when suddenly roused to any exertion, he speedily sinks again into apparent lifelessness.

question: The sea, or rather the vast river of [MASK], wound among its dependent mountains, whose aerial summits hung over its recesses.
source_info: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus by Shelley, Mary W.
title: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus
prev_sentence: I remained in a recess of the rock, gazing on this wonderful and stupendous scene.
next_sentence: Their icy and glittering peaks shone in the sunlight over the clouds.

question: His power and threats were not omitted in my calculations; a creature who could exist in the ice-caves of the glaciers and hide himself from pursuit among the ridges of inaccessible [MASK] was a being possessing faculties it would be vain to cope with.
source_info: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus by Shelley, Mary W.
title: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus
prev_sentence: I thought of the promise of virtues which he had displayed on the opening of his existence and the subsequent blight of all kindly feeling by the loathing and scorn which his protectors had manifested towards him.
next_sentence: After a long pause of reflection I concluded that the justice due both to him and my fellow creatures demanded of me that I should comply with his request.

question: Learn from me, if not by my [MASK], at least by my example, how dangerous is the acquirement of knowledge and how much happier that man is who believes his native town to be the world, than he who aspires to become greater than his nature will allow.
source_info: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus by Shelley, Mary W.
title: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus
prev_sentence: I will not lead you on, unguarded and ardent as I then was, to your destruction and infallible misery.
next_sentence: When I found so astonishing a power placed within my hands, I hesitated a long time concerning the manner in which I should employ it.

question: Frankenstein is modest; an excellent quality in a [MASK] man.
source_info: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus by Shelley, Mary W.
title: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus

question: It is so long before the mind can persuade itself that she whom we saw every day and whose very existence appeared a part of our own can have departed for everâthat the brightness of a beloved eye can have been extinguished and the sound of a [MASK] so familiar and dear to the ear can be hushed, never more to be heard.
source_info: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus by Shelley, Mary W.
title: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus
prev_sentence: I need not describe the feelings of those whose dearest ties are rent by that most irreparable evil, the void that presents itself to the soul, and the despair that is exhibited on the countenance.
next_sentence: These are the reflections of the first days; but when the lapse of time proves the reality of the evil, then the actual bitterness of grief commences.

question: Yet it is in your power to recompense me, and deliver them from an evil which it only remains for you to [MASK] so great, that not only you and your family, but thousands of others, shall be swallowed up in the whirlwinds of its rage.
source_info: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus by Shelley, Mary W.
title: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus
prev_sentence: I am miserable, and they shall share my wretchedness.
next_sentence: Let your compassion be moved, and do not disdain me.

question: My ardour was indeed the astonishment of the students, and my [MASK] that of the masters.

title: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus
prev_sentence: As I applied so closely, it may be easily conceived that my progress was rapid.
next_sentence: Professor Krempe often asked me, with a sly smile, how Cornelius Agrippa went on, whilst M. Waldman expressed the most heartfelt exultation in my progress.

prev_sentence: For a few moments I gazed with delight on her dark eyes, fringed by deep lashes, and her lovely lips; but presently my rage returned; I remembered that I was for ever deprived of the delights that such beautiful creatures could bestow and that she whose resemblance I contemplated would, in regarding me, have changed that air of divine benignity to one expressive of disgust and affright.

question: My father [MASK] this change with pleasure, and he turned his thoughts towards the best method of eradicating the remains of my melancholy, which every now and then would return by fits, and with a devouring blackness overcast the approaching sunshine.

question: Blasted as thou wert, my agony was still superior to thine, for the bitter sting of remorse will not cease to [MASK] in my wounds until death shall close them for ever.
source_info: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus by Shelley, Mary W.
title: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus
prev_sentence: But it was not so; thou didst seek my extinction, that I might not cause greater wretchedness; and if yet, in some mode unknown to me, thou hadst not ceased to think and feel, thou wouldst not desire against me a vengeance greater than that which I feel.

prev_sentence: âBut soon,â he cried with sad and solemn enthusiasm, âI shall die, and what I now feel be no longer felt.

question: For this was it a glorious, for this was it an honourable [MASK].
source_info: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus by Shelley, Mary W.
title: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus
prev_sentence: Not because the way was smooth and placid as a southern sea, but because it was full of dangers and terror, because at every new incident your fortitude was to be called forth and your courage exhibited, because danger and death surrounded it, and these you were to brave and overcome.
next_sentence: You were hereafter to be hailed as the benefactors of your species, your names adored as belonging to brave men who encountered death for honour and the benefit of mankind.

question: Is not this a [MASK] country? â âAy, sir, free enough for honest folks.

title: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus
prev_sentence: The girl met him at the door, helped to relieve him of his burden, and taking some of the fuel into the cottage, placed it on the fire; then she and the youth went apart into a nook of the cottage, and he showed her a large loaf and a piece of cheese.
next_sentence: She afterwards continued her work, whilst the young man went into the garden and appeared busily employed in digging and pulling up roots.

question: One inscription that he left was in these [MASK]: âPrepare!
source_info: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus by Shelley, Mary W.
title: Frankenstein; Or, The Modern Prometheus
prev_sentence: The triumph of my enemy increased with the difficulty of my labours.
next_sentence: Your toils only begin; wrap yourself in furs and provide food, for we shall soon enter upon a journey where your sufferings will satisfy my everlasting hatred.â  My courage and perseverance were invigorated by these scoffing words; I resolved not to fail in my purpose, and calling on Heaven to support me, I continued with unabated fervour to traverse immense deserts, until the ocean appeared at a distance and formed the utmost boundary of the horizon.
